lines.text: Don't let the ghosts and the ghouls disturb you, love.
Darling, the only ghoul in the house is you!
Only the ghosts in this house are glad we're here.
Don't stay up thinking of ways to get rid of me, it makes wrinkles.
Do you remember the fun we had when you poisoned me?

[laughs]
Something you ate, the doctor said.
Yes, arsenic on the rocks...
[grabs Annabelle]
Annabelle, you'd do it again if you thought you'd get away with it, wouldn't you?
If I were gonna haunt somebody, this would certainly be the house I'd do it in.
Who would want to haunt me?
I would say any self-respecting male ghost.

[shows everyone a knife]
This is what she used on my brother and her sister, hacked them to pieces. We found parts of their bodies all over the house, in places you wouldn't think. A funny thing is the heads have never been found - hands and feet and things like that, but no heads.
The wife, probably in a fit of rage, threatened her husband with the knife, and then, carried away by hysteria, took a swing at him and simply went on from there.

[laughing]
She certainly went on. How many people did she kill, Mr. Pritchard?
Only two, her husband and her sister, nobody else was here.
So there are two loose heads just floating around here someplace?
You can hear them at night, they whisper to each other, and then cry.

[opening lines]
The ghosts are moving tonight, restless... hungry. May I introduce myself? I'm Watson Pritchard. In just a moment I'll show you the only really haunted house in the world. Since it was built a century ago, seven people, including my brother, have been murdered in it. Since then, I've owned the house. I only spent one night then and when they found me in the morning, I... I was almost dead.

[to Annabelle]
At last you've got it all, everything I had... even my life. But you're not going to live to enjoy it! Come with me, murderess, come with me!
It's a pity you didn't know when you started your game of murder that I was playing, too.
Pritchard, I've had enough of your spook talk.
[starts shaking up bottle of champagne]
Why do you always do that? It spoils the champagne.
It might explode.
Never does.
Can you guarantee that?
[aims champagne bottle at Annabelle]
That isn't funny, Frederick.
Make a good headline, "Playboy kills wife with champagne cork."
Mr. Pritchard here promises us genuine ghosts.
Seven now. Maybe more before morning.
You're in danger here - we all are.
From who?
I hope for your sake you never find out.
You know, of course, that I'm his fourth wife. The first simply disappeared; the other two died.
My husband is sometimes insane with jealousy. Nothing matters to him!
Would he hurt you?
He would kill me if he could.
Would you adore me as much if I were poor? No, all you want to be is a lovely widow.
It's almost time to lock up the house and then your party will really begin. I wonder how it will end...
Oh, I'm sure we're not going to go running around the house shooting each other, aren't you?
Wasn't there a man who threw his wife into a wine vat or something?
That was in the cellar. There's been a murder almost everywhere in this house.
I am not such a fool as to hang my wife from the ceiling, by a rope!

[looking at blood stain on ceiling]
See that stain? Blood. A young girl was killed here... and whatever got her wasn't human.
[last lines]
They're coming for me now...
[looks at camera]
...and then they'll come for you.

[Nora has encountered the organ that plays by itself and runs screaming through the house]
Did you hear anything?
Organ music?
That... and someone walking.
[repeated line]

[on his wife]
She's so amusing.
Nora, I think you're a little upset. Would you care for a sedative?
Get out! Get out all of you! All of you get out and leave me alone! Just get out of here!
I'm going to my room and if anybody comes in, I'll shoot him.
[looking at Ruth]
Or her.
Would you go away for a million dollars tax free
[Annabelle smiles and shakes her head]
Of course not, you want it all don't you.
I deserve it all, your jealousy isn't tax free and your possessiveness is maddening.
If ever a man had grounds for divorce.
But can't prove them.
And you call this a party?
Could be.
What husband hasn't, at some time, wanted to kill his wife? What husband hasn't had a thousand opportunities to do it in such a way so that he'd never be suspected?

I am Frederick Loren, and I have rented the house on Haunted Hill tonight so that my wife can give a party. She's so amusing. There'll be food and drink and ghosts, and perhaps even a few murders. You're all invited. If any of you will spend the next twelve hours in this house, I will give you each ten thousand dollars, or your next of kin in case you don't survive. Ah, but here come our other guests.
Mr. Pritchard, you said your sister-in-law killed a man and a woman here and cut them up?
[he nods]
You said they found hands and feet but they never found any heads.
[shakes his head]
Would you like to see one of those heads?
[turns to everybody else]
Would you all like to see one of those heads? Well then come with me.

[about Frederick's previous wives]
All his doctors said heart attacks. Two girls in their 20s. Lance... I don't want to join them.

[to Nora]
Come with us, come with us before he kills you!
Dr. Trent, don't you approve of our little party favors?
Suppose Nora had a gun when she was alone in the cellar with the blind woman?
Oh, I don't think anyone else is going to walk around in total darkness.
Oh, I'm sure we're not going to go running around the house shooting each other, aren't you?
Who knows? Fear can make people do amazing things.

[about the guns they're given]
These are no good against the dead, only the living.
Throw these guns away, they won't be any good.
I agree with Pritchard, although not for the same reason.

It was my wife's idea to have our guests come in funeral cars. Her sense of humor is, shall we say, original? She's so amusing. I dreamed up the hearse, it's empty now but after a night in the house on Haunted Hill, who knows?

The caretakers will leave at midnight, locking us in here until they come back in the morning. Once the door is locked, there's no way out. The windows have bars that a jail would be proud of, and the only door to the outside locks like vault. There's no electricity, no phone, no one within miles, so no way to call for help.
Like a coffin.

This is Lance Schroeder, a test pilot. He's no doubt a brave man, but don't you think you can be much braver if you're paid for it? And I happen to know that Lance needs the ten thousand I'm giving, if he's brave enough to stay all night.

This is Ruth Bridges, you've no doubt read her column in the newspapers. She says that her reason for coming to the party is to write a feature article on ghosts. She's also desperate for money, gambles...
You've already met Watson Pritchard, a man living in mortal fear of a house and yet he is risking his life to spend another night here. I wonder why? He says for money.
This is Doctor David Trent, a psychiatrist. He claims that my ghosts will help his work on hysteria, but don't you see a little touch of greed around the mouth and eyes?
This is Nora Manning, I picked her from the thousands of people who work for me because she needed the ten thousand more than most. She supports her whole family. Isn't she pretty?
The party's starting now, and you have until midnight to find the house on Haunted Hill.

[Lance is found in a 'locked' room with a head injury he attributed to bumping it]
I wonder why they didn't kill him.
Who?
He didn't bump his head, they hit him.
They?
Four men have been murdered in this house, and three women.
You certainly plan your parties very well, Mr. Loren, four of us are men, three are women, there's a ghost for everybody.

[shows severed head found in Nora's closet]
What do you know about this?
They've taken her. In a little while she'll be one of them.
WHERE'S NORA? Where is she?
It's too late, it's too late, you'll never find her again!
Pritchard, if you know where she is you better tell me now!
She's gone! She's gone with them, and there's nothing you can do about it.
[a woman screams from somewhere in the house, then chokes and becomes silent]

[comes around corner, whispering]
Lance, hide me, please, hide me!
What?
Hide me!
[they go to his room and lock the door, she regains her voice]
He tried to kill me! He grabbed me and choked me and put me in that room, and then he went away and left me!
Who?
He thought I was dead!
Who?
Mr. Loren.
Are you sure about this?
I don't know, it was dark but it must've been him.
Has anybody seen you since he left you?
I don't know. I heard some people in that room but I went by and nobody saw me.
Mrs. Loren is dead.
But how?
Loren said she committed suicide, but I think somebody killed her.
Him?
Do you think it would do any good if you went in and talked to her?
Well, do you think there really was a head in her suitcase?
I don't know.
A thing like that would put me right over the edge.

[grabs Pritchard by the throat]
What are you doing in here?
Wait! No, wait!
What do you mean coming in here?
I didn't want them to take her away!
You're drunk!
They will if you don't watch her!
You're drunk! Alright, out with it, Pritchard. Why did you come into this room?
I'm the only one that understands.
Understands what?
Your wife isn't there anymore. She's already joined them!
What's the use of saying, "Good night"?
